Cognate with Old Saxon libbian (Middle Low German leven, German Low German lÄ™ven, lewen (â€œto liveâ€)), Dutch leven, English live, West Frisian libje, Old Norse lifa (Swedish leva), Gothic ğŒ»ğŒ¹ğŒ±ğŒ°ğŒ½ (liban).

Verb[edit]

leben (third-person singular simple present lebt, past tense lebte, past participle gelebt, auxiliary haben)

  1. (intransitive) to live, to be alive
  2. (intransitive) to dwell, to reside
    • 2010, Der Spiegel, issue 35/2010, page 102:
      Es leben etwa 300 000 BÃ¼rger des ehemaligen Jugoslawien in der Schweiz, kaum ein Staat hat damals im VerhÃ¤ltnis zu seiner Einwohnerzahl so viele FlÃ¼chtlinge aufgenommen.
      There are (=reside) about 300,000 citizens of the former Yugoslavia living in Switzerland, hardly any state took in so many refugees in relation to its population at that time.
    Ich lebe in der SchillerstraÃŸe in der NÃ¤he des Stadtzentrums. - I live in the Schiller-street near the city's center.
  3. (intransitive) to live, to exist, to occupy a place
    Die Dinosaurier lebten fÃ¼r Jahrmillionen auf der Erde bevor der Mensch erschien. - The dinosaurs existed on Earth for millions of years prior to the rise of man.
  4. (intransitive, hyperbolic) To cope with, to live with, to deal with.
    Du wirst wohl damit leben mÃ¼ssen! - You'll have to cope with it!
    Jeder muss mit seinen eigenen Problemen leben! - Everybody has to deal with his own issues.
